column1:
0'EGYRZP5OC'Dear Princess Programmer: Keep Coding!'"

Yesterday I was checking my feed on Twitter when I saw one of my followers commenting on this tweet. This tweet was sharing screenshots of a post found on the Reddit forum r/AmItheAsshole forum. The original post has since been removed by the moderators
column2: but screenshots and cross postings can still be found in other Reddit forums.

column1: Hi programmers would you like to be incandescent with rage?
A lot of comments were quick to point that this story had to be fake and this author had to be a troll just trying to create a reaction to get attention. Regardless if it was fake or not
column2: the post quickly got reactions the author was wanting with 351 comments already responding to the original post. Many of these comments were criticizing him for how he handled the situation as well as his view of ""programming being serious and not a game""
column3: telling his daughter to stop with the princess programmer stuff
column4: and even saying C++ is outdated.

column1: As DEV gets ready to end the WeCoded celebration this year
column2: I want to use this year's post to reach out to Princess Programmer. While there's a lot of focus on her father
column3: I want to use this post to reach out to his daughter to let her know that she inspires me as a programmer and I hope she continues to code. I can't speak for the rest of the tech community
column4: but I think is is awesome she taught herself C++ and created her own game. Those are two big accomplishments she should be very proud of herself for. I hope she will feel ready to publish her game someday so little kids can play it and inspire others to create their own games too.

column1: If she needs a mentor or someone to support her as she continues to learn how to code
column2: there are tons of organizations and communities that can support. I'm also certain there are many developers that would also love to mentor her and help her out if she needs it too. So please don't hesitate to reach out and ask.

I hope she continues to keep being a princess programmer and what that means to her. One of the reasons I love tech is because tech allows everyone to bring what makes them special to the table so they can create awesome things. Tech needs more people like princess programmer in it and I hope she never gives up on that.

column1: If there is anything we can learn from this Reddit post is the power a mentor can have and it makes a difference in breaking down the barriers in tech. Good and bad mentors do leave an impact that can leave a lasting influence new developers. This whole situation reminded me of the TV show Scrubs. In episode 17
column2: J.D. is given a med student to teach and he gets so frustrated by his student's mistakes that he tells the student he shouldn't be a doctor. When he discovers that his student quits
column3: he tries getting confirmation from others at the hospital that what happened wasn't his fault. Carla doesn't buy it and tells him that he was the one that failed since he was his teacher.

column1: Carla's point is spot and it should serve as a reminder for all of us in tech about what it means to be a mentor or a teacher. Mentoring is much more than helping another developer figure out a problem or learn a new skill. Many times mentors are the first cheerleaders we have and can leave a lasting impact on the people they help.
Tech still is addressing a lot of issues so it is more equitable and diverse. In order to make this a reality
column2: it starts by mentoring and supporting programmers like Princess Programmer so we don't miss on what they bring to tech. As WeCoded gets ready to end
column3: I hope reading this post reminds everyone why this celebration is important and gives others the courage to mentor new developers coming into tech or at least cheer on their own princess programmers in their own lives.

column1: Janna Loeffler's tweet responding to the Reddit post is the best way to end this one. I hope if Princess Programmer reads this someday she sees all the support she has gotten from others in tech and how we are all sending her lots of love her way.
@eterry28 @laceynwilliams @techgirl1908 @ParissAthena @ladyleet @TheyWrestleTest @bria_sullivan @TaraWithTiaras Much love from one Princess Programmer to another. (Yes
column2: I did wear that to work‚Ä¶ yes
column3: I did work for Disney at the time)

column1:
1'S47PDXIYE'Serverless & Well Architected'"

Over the last few days
column2: we've discussed a number of topics in the serverless space
column3: covering storage
column6: and everything in between. We've got all the components to build a fully functional
column8: but before you run off and create The Next Big Thing
column9: we have to cover one more crucial topic: Well Architected. The Well Architected Framework is a set of guidelines or best practices that AWS introduced a few years ago. The six ""pillars"" of Well Architected are Security
column14: and Sustainability. These concepts are not new
column15: but by defining them in this way
column16: AWS has established a reference that is easy to use and understand when evaluating your applications for best practices. In fact
column17: AWS has created a Well Architected Tool & Review process centered around the six pillars
column18: asking you questions about your application to review yourself or with your team. Before you start building your application
column19: I would highly recommend you go through a formal Well Architected Review. You don't need to answer every single question
column20: in fact some might not be applicable
column21: but going through this exercise gets you thinking about how you want to architect your application
column23: or potential issues that you haven't thought of just yet. In the subsections that follow
column24: we'll talk about each of the pillars in a little more detail
column25: and I'll briefly cover Well Architected Lenses.

column2: how are you securing your app? Are you using authorization and authentication with <a href=""https://docs.aws.amazon.com/IAM/latest/UserGuide/introduction.html"">IAM users
column3: roles
column4: and policies to limit access to your resources? Setting up permission boundaries and using KMS keys for encryption? This can look like any number of measures
column5: but the important idea here is
column6: are you thinking about how to secure your app? Some of the questions in this space may not be applicable. This could be an app just for you
column7: or one that isn't storing any data to worry about
column8: or it could be wide open to the public and have no personal information to worry about. You don't need to have every single security measure in place for your application
column9: but you do need to think about these things

column1: This one is pretty straightforward‚Ää-‚ÄäI don't know anyone who gets excited when their cost or bills go up in price. Obviously
column2: we all want to optimize for a low-cost application solution
column3: whether this is for personal use
column5: or the company you work for (you may not care about that one personally
column6: but I can tell you THEY certainly care about the bottom line). Look at the pricing model and see if there are any ways to cut costs. Some easy ones could be to minimize the number of API calls you're making
column7: or utilize Lambda Powertools to optimize your lambda function for memory & performance. If you've exhausted every option here
column8: that's okay. Cost is typically a trade-off; you may be ok spending more money to make sure your application is secure
column10: and not hindered in performance. Again
column11: the idea here is that you're actively aware of where your money is going
column12: and you've reviewed your optimization options thoroughly.

column1: One of my favorite topics to talk about is 'Clean Code'
column2: or better known as best practices within your code. Although this could cover many of these pillars
column3: it arguably fits squarely within Operational Excellence. This pillar is all about building robust applications
column4: code that is easy to understand
column7: and having effective development processes in place. Creating small
column15: and so much more fall into this category. For me
column16: this one is sort of like a ""catch all"" pillar; not because it isn't well defined
column17: but because it encompasses so many parts of the application development cycle. Many of the pillars overlap
column18: but it is very likely that this one in particular will have overlap with one or more of the other pillars at any given time.

column1: Is your application stable? Do you backup your data regularly? Do you have failovers or other fail-safe measures in place? Can your application handle a large influx of traffic
column2: or will any changes to the 'average' case break your current functionality? The key question this pillar asks is‚Ää-‚Ääare you prepared? Outages are never fun
column3: especially when they significantly impact your customers
column4: but they can (and they do) happen to the best of us. By reviewing the questions in the reliability pillar
column5: you are thinking about your application's disaster recovery plans
column7: and having processes in place for the 'worst-case scenario'. Hopefully by completing a reliability review
column8: these things don't occur as often
column9: or aren't as widespread as they might've been before a review.

column1: Closely related to the Operational Excellence and Reliability pillars
column2: the Performance Efficiency pillar is
column3: you guessed it
column4: all about how well your application is performing. What I enjoy most about this pillar is if you're taking advantage of serverless architectures
column5: you're already well on your way to having this one covered
column6: as it's one of the five design principles to adhere to. This is about your application running smoothly
column8: and taking advantage of only the resources you need. This is another big ""trade-off"" pillar
column9: since you may compromise your performance in some cases to comply with security or save on cost.

column1: Sustainability is a recent addition to the Well Architected pillars
column2: and I think it's a good one. It was introduced at the end of 2021
column3: and even though it's a focus I love to see
column4: it also means there has not been a ton of guidance shared to optimize for sustainability. If you're invested in areas involving hardware
column9: this is a bit more obvious to contend to‚Ää-‚Ääsimply put
column10: you want to use less resources
column11: and more sustainable (or at least recyclable) hardware. WIth serverless
column13: only paying for what you use
column14: and optimizing for your event driven architecture
column15: which makes it more difficult to find areas to cut down on usage. My best advice is to review your architecture early & often
column16: and continually try to find ways to <a href=""https://www.nature.org/en-us/get-involved/how-to-help/carbon-footprint-calculator/#:~:text=A%20carbon%20footprint%20is%20the
column17: is%20closer%20to%204%20tons."">lower your carbon footprint with optimal architectural design
column18: and if you haven't made the jump to serverless yet

column2: AWS Well Architected has this concept of Well Architected Lenses. Much like a pair of reading glasses
column3: you can apply a specific Lens to your application to 'see' your application in a bit more detail. There are Lenses for Machine Learning
column8: Serverless Applications. These Lenses are simply a set of extra guidelines and questions for each of these six pillars relating specifically to the type of application you are building. They are 'optional'
column9: as is the entire Well Architected Review process
column11: if you are building a serverless application
column12: I would highly recommend you complete a Well Architected Review with the Serverless Lens
column13: as it will only strengthen your application posture in the context of these six pillars.

column1: If you'd like to learn more about Well Architected or hear about it in practice
column2: I have actually given a recent talk on the subject with Build On at AWS Re:Invent. This is an area of technology I have been very passionate about
column3: and I truly believe these pillars and Well Architected Reviews are well worth the time and effort. We're coming up to end of our team together this week (I know
column4: already?!) so for our last day tomorrow
column5: I'm excited to summarize what we've learned so far
column6: and present you with some next steps for going beyond the serverless basics.*

column1: *This is part of a series that will be covered here
column2:
but I also encourage you to follow along with the rest of the series on 90DaysOfDevOps.

"'https://dev.to/aws-heroes/serverless-well-architected-40jn'https://res.cloudinary.com/practicaldev/image/fetch/s--H5E5fa48--/c_imagga_scale

In this post we're going to see how the SQL JOIN works
column2: guided by a practical example while covering SQL and Set theory basics.

column1: Even though you're not familiar with SQL
column2: you can follow along as this post covers the very basics.
every time I want to explain something

The examples described here were tested using PostgreSQL 15.
Despite SQL being a standard DSL that should work on any RDBMS

let's start the journey to understanding SQL JOINs.
tables are related to set theory in mathematics. Usually

• the columns in both sets must be in the same order

column2: by%20the%20two%20SELECT%20statements."">INTERSECT operator also combines the result of two or more sets

3) AS id
'User-' || id AS name

the query returned only the identical rows found in both sets. That's exactly the ""intersection"" between the two sets.
which in the set theory is the DIFFERENCE (A - B).

column1: This operator also combines the result of two or more sets
column2: but only return rows of the first set (first SELECT) that are not present in the second set (second SELECT).
'User-' || id AS name
3) AS id
'User-' || id AS name
5) AS id;

column1: Just 1 row. The only one that is present in the first set (left) but not in the second (right). We can also invert the sets and get the differences in reverse:

column2: 'User-' || id AS name
5) AS id
'User-' || id AS name
3) AS id;

column1: Once we understand some SQL basics and how those relate to set theory in mathematics
column2: it's time to go beyond and explore a more sophisticated example.
we've been experimenting SQL operators with sets on the fly by using the generate_series PostgreSQL function.

column1: Did you notice that we haven't create any table? That's a good alternative to experiment and learn ad hoc.
But for a more sophisticated example we'll start persisting data into pyshical tables.

column2: we can define a structure for a particular set of elements.

column1: Such table structure is represented by a matrix of rows and columns
column2: where rows are essentially a collection of values whereas columns define the type of values.

column1: CREATE TABLE users (id INTEGER
column2: name VARCHAR(250));

column1: id is the name of the first column. It only allows values of type integer
name is the name of the second column. It only allows values of type ""character varying up to 250 bytes"" (VARCHAR(250))

there's no data inserted into the table. Let's insert some data.

INSERT INTO users (id

column1: SELECT * FROM movies;

it's time to explore some other operations between users and movies.
a cartesian product is a combination of every element from one set to every element of another set.

Let's create another table called movies_ratings that associates:

column2: and because its structure differs form the other two tables
column3: we can no longer use basic set operators such as <em>UNION
column4: INTERSECT or EXCEPT to combine data between different tables.

column2: but not doing every combination
column3: only under certain conditions

column1: That's what we're going to explore in the next section: a world of JOINs.

column2: we can combine rows across different tables but applying a specific condition.

column1: The clause may have different types of JOIN depending on the situation.
In case we want to combine all data from the first table (left) with the second table (right)
column2: but discarding the rows that do not appear in both tables
column3: we use INNER JOIN.

column1: Should we combine all the values from users with movies_ratings
column2: discarding rows that don't appear in both tables:

column1: SELECT * FROM users
INNER JOIN movies_ratings ON movies_ratings.user_id = users.id;
<pre class=""highlight plaintext""><code> id | name | user_id | movie_id | rating

column2: so Kate was discarded in the INNER JOIN
we can use INNER JOIN or simply JOIN. By default
column3: without specifying the JOIN type

column1: But what if we wanted to display even Kate in the JOIN but with null values? In other words
column2: how to keep every row in both tables even if the condition wasn't satisfied?

column1: The SQL FULL OUTER JOIN will keep every row from both tables even if the condition wasn't satisfied.
SELECT * FROM users
FULL OUTER JOIN movies_ratings ON movies_ratings.user_id = users.id;
<pre class=""highlight plaintext""><code> id | name | user_id | movie_id | rating

column2: we can use FULL OUTER JOIN or simply FULL JOIN
SQL provides another type of JOIN
column3: which combines two tables (left and right) but keeps all rows from the left table only
column4: even if they do not appear in the right table.

column2: we are talking about the LEFT OUTER JOIN.

column1: The SQL LEFT OUTER JOIN will keep every row from the left table even if they do not appear in the right table.
SELECT * FROM users
LEFT OUTER JOIN movies_ratings ON movies_ratings.user_id = users.id;
<pre class=""highlight plaintext""><code> id | name | user_id | movie_id | rating

column2: we can use LEFT OUTER JOIN or simply LEFT JOIN
there's also the opposite direction: RIGHT OUTER JOIN.

column1: The SQL RIGHT OUTER JOIN will keep every row from the right table even if they do not appear in the left table.
Please note that we'll invert the tables
column2: movies_ratings will be the left table whereas users will be the right table:

column1: SELECT * FROM movies_ratings
RIGHT OUTER JOIN users ON movies_ratings.user_id = users.id;
<pre class=""highlight plaintext""><code> user_id | movie_id | rating | id | name

column2: in case we applied LEFT JOIN
column3: Kate would be discarded.

column1: But as we applied RIGHT JOIN (users are in the right-side)
column2: Kate was kept in the JOIN even not appearing in the left table movies_ratings.
we can use RIGHT OUTER JOIN or simply RIGHT JOIN

column1: Now that we understand about different JOIN strategies in SQL
column2: let's build a query where we display:

column1: Let's write the query in baby steps.

column2: we project the fields in SELECT:
we should JOIN movies and movies_ratings tables.
we'll perform a LEFT JOIN with the movies_ratings
column3: because we want to keep all users even those who didin't vote.

column1: LEFT JOIN movies_ratings ON users.id = movies_ratings.user_id
The following step consists of joining the movies table as well.
But keep in mind that at this moment
column2: the left table is the result of the first join and the right table will be the movies table.
Kate will be discarded as she doesn't appear in the movies table. We then should use LEFT JOIN as well:

column1: LEFT JOIN movies_ratings ON users.id = movies_ratings.user_id
LEFT JOIN movies ON movies.id = movies_ratings.movie_id

column2: let's order the results by rating in descending order.
in the ORDER clause
column3: we'll perform the NULLS LAST
column4: so Kate will appear at the bottom of the results

column1: users.name AS user
movies.name AS movie
LEFT JOIN movies_ratings ON users.id = movies_ratings.user_id
LEFT JOIN movies ON movies.id = movies_ratings.movie_id
ORDER BY movies_ratings.rating DESC NULLS LAST;
What if I wanted to discard users who didn't vote in the results?

column2: you just need to perform an INNER JOIN
column3: remember?

column1: JOIN movies_ratings ON users.id = movies_ratings.user_id
JOIN movies ON movies.id = movies_ratings.movie_id

column2: we want to display a query which only brings the number of votes for each user. Then it should display as follows:
we return all users JOINed with movies_ratings
column3: projecting the users.name field:

column1: LEFT JOIN movies_ratings ON users.id = movies_ratings.user_id

column2: we want to group users by their names. In SQL
column3: we can use the clause GROUP BY.

column1: LEFT JOIN movies_ratings ON users.id = movies_ratings.user_id

column2: we want to project another field in the SELECT
column3: which are the count of votes of each user.

column2: which does the job: you can count on an arbitrary field that belongs to a selected projection.

column1: COUNT(movies_ratings.rating) AS votes
LEFT JOIN movies_ratings ON users.id = movies_ratings.user_id

column2: let's order by the counter of votes
column3: so Kate with 0 votes will appear at the bottom:

column1: COUNT(movies_ratings.rating) AS votes
LEFT JOIN movies_ratings ON users.id = movies_ratings.user_id
ORDER BY COUNT(movies_ratings.rating) DESC;

column2: voil√†:

column1: This post was a try to explain the basics of SQL and set theory
column2: along with a practical example towards an explanation of different JOIN strategies.

column1: I hope you could learn a bit more about SQL JOIN and SQL in general.

preferimos usar plurais

column1: o cliente est√° solicitando recuperar um recurso da cole√ß√£o de um usu√°rio com o id 123. Ao criar um recurso

column1: N√£o misture substantivos singulares e plurais. Mantenha a simplicidade e use apenas substantivos no plural para todos os recursos.
Deixe o Verbo HTTP Definir a A√ß√£o

column3: POST
column5: DELETE) definirem a a√ß√£o a ser realizada em um recurso.

column1: POST: √â utilizado para criar um novo registro no banco de dados.
GET: √â utilizado para ler registros no banco de dados.

column1: A autentica√ß√£o e autoriza√ß√£o em APIs REST devem ser stateless. Cada solicita√ß√£o deve ser auto-suficiente e atendida sem conhecimento da solicita√ß√£o anterior. Isso √© especialmente importante para autorizar a√ß√µes de usu√°rios.

column7: √© poss√≠vel gerar documenta√ß√£o de API atualizada e precisa com apenas algumas linhas de c√≥digo.

column1: Use c√≥digos de status HTTP para fornecer a resposta a um cliente. Pode ser uma resposta de sucesso ou falha
column2: mas deve definir o que o sucesso ou falha respectivo significa do ponto de vista do servidor.

column1: Abaixo est√£o as categorias de respostas por seus c√≥digos de status:
200 OK: Retornado por uma opera√ß√£o GET ou DELETE bem-sucedida. PUT ou POST tamb√©m podem usar isso
column2: se o servi√ßo n√£o quiser retornar um recurso de volta ao cliente ap√≥s a cria√ß√£o ou modifica√ß√£o.

column1: 201 Created: Resposta para uma cria√ß√£o de recurso bem-sucedida por uma solicita√ß√£o POST.
304 Not Modified: Usado se o cabe√ßalho de cache HTTP for implementado.
400 Bad Request: Quando o corpo da solicita√ß√£o HTTP n√£o pode ser analisado. Por exemplo
column2: se uma API estiver esperando um corpo em formato JSON para uma solicita√ß√£o POST
column3: mas o corpo da solicita√ß√£o estiver malformado.

column1: 401 Unauthorized: A autentica√ß√£o n√£o foi bem-sucedida (ou as credenciais n√£o foram fornecidas) ao acessar a API.
403 Forbidden: Se um usu√°rio n√£o est√° autorizado a realizar uma a√ß√£o
column2: embora as informa√ß√µes de autentica√ß√£o estejam corretas.

column1: 404 Not Found: Se o recurso solicitado n√£o estiver dispon√≠vel no servidor.
405 Method Not Allowed: Se o usu√°rio estiver tentando violar um contrato de API
column2: por exemplo
column3: tentando atualizar um recurso usando um m√©todo POST.

column1: 409 Conflict: O servidor n√£o p√¥de completar a solicita√ß√£o devido a um conflito com o estado atual do recurso.
422 Unprocessable Entity: O servidor entende o tipo de conte√∫do da solicita√ß√£o
column2: mas n√£o pode process√°-lo devido a erros sem√¢nticos.

column1: Esses erros ocorrem devido a falhas do servidor ou problemas com a infraestrutura subjacente.

√â importante lembrar que esses s√£o alguns dos status codes mais comuns e amplamente utilizados. Existem muitos outros c√≥digos de status HTTP que podem ser usados para fornecer uma resposta mais precisa ao cliente. Para obter uma lista completa e detalhada de todos os c√≥digos de status HTTP
column2: voc√™ pode acessar a documenta√ß√£o oficial no seguinte link: https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc7231.

column1: √â importante lembrar que seguir as boas pr√°ticas de design de APIs RESTful n√£o s√≥ torna a API mais f√°cil de usar
column2: mas tamb√©m melhora a seguran√ßa
column3: escalabilidade e manuten√ß√£o do servi√ßo. Ao utilizar os padr√µes e princ√≠pios discutidos neste artigo
column4: voc√™ poder√° criar APIs mais confi√°veis
column5: flex√≠veis e f√°ceis de evoluir. Al√©m disso
column6:
a maturidade das APIs pode ser facilmente documentada usando o Modelo de Maturidade Richardson.

4'50ZO8S7ZX'üí• Top 10 JavaScript Libraries and Frameworks to Watch in 2023 üí•'"

JavaScript is a versatile programming language that powers most of the web applications we use today. With the increasing demand for dynamic and interactive web applications
column2: JavaScript libraries and frameworks have become essential tools for developers. In this article
column3: we will explore the üîù top 10 JavaScript libraries and frameworks that are expected to gain popularity in 2023.

column1: React is a popular front-end library for building dynamic user interfaces. It has a vast community and is widely used by big tech companies. React enables developers to create reusable UI components that can be used across multiple pages
column2: making development more efficient.

column1: Vue.js is another front-end framework that has gained popularity in recent years. It is a progressive framework that enables developers to build scalable and performant user interfaces. Vue.js is also known for its simplicity and easy-to-learn syntax
column2: making it a popular choice for beginners.

column1: Angular is a comprehensive front-end framework that enables developers to build complex web applications. It provides a robust set of features
column2: including two-way data binding
column3: dependency injection
column4: and component-based architecture. Angular is widely used in enterprise-level applications and is backed by Google.

column1: React Native is a cross-platform mobile development framework based on React. It enables developers to build native mobile applications using JavaScript
column2: allowing them to reuse code across multiple platforms. React Native is widely used by mobile app developers
column3: including Facebook

column1: Express.js is a popular back-end framework that enables developers to build scalable and robust web applications. It provides a simple and minimalist approach to web development
column2: making it easy to create APIs and handle server-side logic.

column1: Next.js is a front-end framework that enables developers to build server-side-rendered React applications. It provides an opinionated and easy-to-use approach to web development
column2: making it a popular choice for building static sites and serverless applications.

column1: Redux is a popular state management library for React applications. It provides a predictable state container that enables developers to manage complex data flows in their applications. Redux is widely used in large-scale applications and is known for its simplicity and ease of use.
GraphQL is a query language for APIs that enables developers to retrieve data efficiently. It provides a flexible and powerful approach to data fetching
column2: allowing developers to retrieve only the data they need. GraphQL is widely used in modern web applications and is supported by big tech companies like Facebook and GitHub.

column1: D3.js is a powerful data visualization library for JavaScript. It enables developers to create interactive and dynamic visualizations using a variety of data sources. D3.js is widely used in data-driven applications and is known for its flexibility and extensibility.

Tensorflow.js is a machine learning library for JavaScript that enables developers to build and train machine learning models in the browser. It provides a powerful and easy-to-use approach to machine learning
column2: allowing developers to create intelligent applications with ease.

JavaScript libraries and frameworks are essential tools for modern web development. The üîù top 10 JavaScript libraries and frameworks we have discussed in this article are expected to gain popularity in 2023 and beyond. Whether you are a beginner or an experienced developer
column3:
these tools can help you build robust and scalable web applications. üöÄ

5'634K4CQMR'üöÄ Ways to Title Case Strings with Javascript'"

As part of a recent fix I had to do during work
column2: I needed to title case an input of a group of sentences that would later be used to validate other logic. The problem was that these sentences needed certain considerations when applying the title case.

even when this is a specific case for a specific need I saw this as a good opportunity to not only use this article to list a few ways to title case sentences but also to share the solution i ended up using and that could probably be of help to someone.

column1: This just means converting to uppercase the first letter of every word in a sentence while the other ones remain in lowercase.
There are different ways you can find and use to convert a sentence to title case in Javascript
column2: here are a few:

column1: function convertToTitleCase(str) {
if (!str) {
return str.toLowerCase().replace(/\b\w/g
column2: s => s.toUpperCase());

column1: console.log(convertToTitleCase('welcome to my article'));
console.log(convertToTitleCase('THE avengers'));

column2: we use regex to match only the first letter of each word to then replace it as uppercase.

column1: Side note: it's good to normalize the string by converting everything first to lowercase before actually converting to title case.
function convertToTitleCase(str) {
if (!str) {
return str.toLowerCase().split(' ').map(function (word) {
return word.charAt(0).toUpperCase().concat(word.substr(1));
}).join(' ');
console.log(convertToTitleCase('welcome AGAIN to MY aRticle'));
console.log(convertToTitleCase('THE avengers MOVIe'));
We first turn the sentence into an array with

column2: when using the map()
column3: this will do a callback function for each element in the array where with

column1: we transform the element and build a new array from the results.
There can be cases where not all words in the sentence would need to be converted
column2: which was the case i run into
column3: here was my solution
column4: which is basically using the map() way but adding the condition to check if the current word was or not eligible for title case.

column1: const exceptions = ['of'
column2: 'the'
column3: 'and'];

column1: if (!str) {
return str.toLowerCase().split(' ').map((word
column2: i) => {

column1: return exceptions.includes(word) && i != 0 ? word : word.charAt(0).toUpperCase().concat(word.substr(1));
}).join(' ');
console.log(convertToTitleCase('lord OF the rings'));
console.log(convertToTitleCase('people AND people'));
console.log(convertToTitleCase('someTHING ABOUT THE article'));
There are many options out there we could use to convert sentences to title case
column2: we just need to go with the one that works best for our needs.
keep in mind that there could be edge cases where converting to title case can be used or adapted to
column3: it will depend on what exactly needs to be accomplished with it and how it's going to be used since there can be scenarios where it will could probably be impossible to always be correct when the input has been transformed.

column1:
6'PL09F6KBF'Upgrading to Next.js 13: Migration Guide'"

Hey there! Are you ready to upgrade your Next.js application from version 12 to version 13 (stable)? Don't worry
column2: I got you covered. This guide will help you upgrade features that work in both the pages and the app directories
column3: and incrementally migrate your existing application from pages to app. Let's get started!

column2: the minimum Node.js version is now v16.8. Check the Node.js documentation for more details.
just run this command using your favorite package manager:

column1: <pre class=""highlight plaintext""><code>npm install next@latest react@latest react-dom@latest

column2: you'll need to upgrade your ESLint version:

column1: Note: You may need to restart the ESLint server in VS Code for the ESLint changes to take effect. Open the Command Palette (cmd+shift+p on Mac; ctrl+shift+p on Windows) and search for ESLint: Restart ESLint Server.
Next.js 13 introduced the new App Router with new features and conventions. The new Router is available in the app directory and co-exists with the pages directory.
Upgrading to Next.js 13 does not require using the new App Router. You can continue using pages with new features that work in both directories
column2: such as the updated Image component
column3: Link component

column1: Next.js 12 introduced new improvements to the Image Component with a temporary import: next/future/image. These improvements included less client-side JavaScript
column2: easier ways to extend and style images
column3: better accessibility

column2: this new behavior is now the default for next/image.

column1: The <Link> Component no longer requires manually adding an <a> tag as a child. This behavior was added as an experimental option in version 12.2 and is now the default. In Next.js 13
column2: <Link> always renders <a> and allows you to forward props to the underlying tag.

column1: The behavior of next/script has been updated to support both pages and app
column2: but some changes need to be made to ensure a smooth migration.

column1:
Version 13 introduces the new next/font module (beta) which gives you the ability to customize your font loading experience while still ensuring great performance and privacy. next/font is supported in both the pages and app directories.

7'I5FX88TEP'Next.js 13 Image Cheatsheet'"

This cheat sheet is meant to provide an overview of the important features and usage of the Next.js Image Component
column2: which helps to optimize and enhance your images.

column1: import Image from 'next/image';
export default function Page() {
alt=""Picture of the author""

column2: can be an internal path or an external URL.

column1: alt: Description of the image for screen readers and search engines.
loader: A custom function used to resolve image URLs.
fill: Boolean that causes the image to fill the parent element.
sizes: A string that provides information about how wide the image will be at different breakpoints.
quality: The quality of the optimized image
column2: an integer between 1 and 100.
the image will be considered high priority and preload.

column1: placeholder: A placeholder to use while the image is loading.
style: Allows passing CSS styles to the underlying image element.
onLoadingComplete: A callback function that is invoked once the image is completely loaded and the placeholder has been removed.
onLoad: A callback function that is invoked when the image is loaded.
onError: A callback function that is invoked if the image fails to load.
loading: The loading behavior of the image. Defaults to lazy.
blurDataURL: A Data URL to be used as a placeholder image before the src image successfully loads.

column2: the source image will be served as-is instead of changing quality
column3: size

column1: Configure the Image Component in next.config.js. The following options are available:
remotePatterns: Configuration required for using external images.
domains: A list of allowed hostnames for external images.

column2: we will be learning about a recent paradigm in the Ethereum and web3 ecosystem called Account Abstraction. Account Abstraction changes how users use their account wallets in terms of blockchain interactions on the ethereum network. We will learn about the origin
column3: implications
column4: the pros and cons and what providers or products are already using it.

column1: Accounts on the Ethereum blockchain can send transactions using their ether (ETH) balances. Depending on the deployment
column2: these accounts are either user-controlled (human) or smart contracts (code-dependent). Therefore
column3: there are two types of account that a user can use to interact with the blockchain.

column1: The Externally Owned Accounts are made up of a cryptographic pair of keys: public and private. They help prove that a transaction was actually signed by the sender and prevent forgeries. Your private key is what you use to sign transactions
column2: so it grants you custody over the funds associated with your account. You never really hold cryptocurrency
column3: you hold private keys ‚Äì the funds are always on Ethereum's ledger. This prevents malicious actors from broadcasting fake transactions because you can always verify the sender of a transaction.

column1: EOAs are much like normal bank accounts. They have an address (IBAN) and a balance (in Ether). Essentially
column2: the EOAs owner possesses a public key pair
column3: of which only he knows the private key. The matching public key is the EOAs ""address"" - the ""IBAN"". Now
column4: only the EOAs owner can transfer Ether (ie ""withdraw or wire money"") from that account - by using the private key in the process. In summary
column5: EOAs are ""directly owned and controlled"" by their respective owners.

column1: These types of account are usually provided by wallet providers llike Metamask
column2: TrustWallet
column3: SafePal etc. and they are the most in use type of accounts by blockchain products consumers.

column1: Contract Accounts are controlled by code executed by the Ethereum Virtual Machine. They are also referred to as a smart contracts. Contract accounts have associated code and data storage
column2: but not private keys. They ‚Äúcontrol themselves‚Äù. These accounts do so in the way determined by their smart contract code.

column1: A contract address hosts a collection of code on Ethereum that executes functions. The functions are executed when a transaction with associated input data (contract interaction) is made. Such addresses are created when a contract is deployed to the blockchain.
In the attempt to spread the adoption of blockchain technologies and products
column2: not just to the technically educated but also the non-technical folks
column3: onboarding to these products and usage has been characterized with poor user experiences because blockchain technologies is associated with a lot of technicalities from setting up accounts

column1: The use of EOAs does not help much with regards to an even near seamless experience as one can experience difficulties like:
<li>Not being able to do multi-transaction (eg: swap
column2: send etc at the same time) leading to paying gas fees for every single transactions.

column1: • No guarantee for account recovery when one looses the private keys and thereby resulting to loss of accounts and funds as the private key is the only means to approve transaction.

column2: there is little wiggle room for customization
column3: as users can‚Äôt create custom logic to include more signers or authorize different keys to sign on to their accounts. This creates a very limiting scope for transactions.

column1: How does Account Abstraction Improves the Users Experience?
With the advent of account abstraction and introduction of smart contract address
column2: there are lots of benefits that will improve user experience in blockchain products. These benefits include and not limited to:

column1: • Account abstraction unifies contract accounts and EOAs. It makes user accounts more ""programmable"". You remove the logic of signing transactions from the account
column2: and you ‚Äúabstract‚Äù it out
column3: hence account abstraction.

column2: you could make batch transaction operations at the same time.

column1: <li>It also allows for enhanced security as you can code the conditions to be met before a transaction could be signed
column2: set transfer limits and also perform multi-factor authentications.

column1: • Social recovery is one of the UX improvements account abstraction provides by avoiding the issue of a single point of failure with the private key.
• It allows the non-custodial blockchain UX to scale.
Smart contract wallets exist today but are challenging to implement because the ethereum virtual machine (EVM) does not support them. Instead
column2: they rely on wrapping relatively complex code around standard Ethereum transactions. Ethereum can change this by allowing smart contracts to initiate transactions
column3: handling the necessary logic in Ethereum smart contracts instead of off-chain. Putting logic into smart contracts also increases Ethereum's decentralization since it removes the need for relayers run by wallet developers to translate messages signed by the user to regular Ethereum transactions.

column1: Currently there are two major proposals on implementing account abstraction to the ethereum network:

EIP-4337 is the first step towards native smart contract wallet support in a decentralized way without requiring changes to the Ethereum protocol. Instead of modifying the consensus layer to support smart contract wallets
column2: a new system is added separately to the normal transaction gossip protocol.

column1: The way wallets work would also change under EIP-4337. Instead of each wallet re-implementing common but complex safety logic
column2: those functions would be outsourced to a global wallet contract known as the entry point. This would handle operations such as paying fees and executing EVM code so that wallet developers can focus on providing excellent user experiences.

column1: Note that EIP-4337 entry point contract was deployed to Ethereum Mainnet on 1st March 2023.
EIP-2938 aims to update the Ethereum protocol by introducing a new transaction type
column2: AA_TX_TYPE that includes three fields: nonce
column3: target and data
column5: target is the entry point contract address and data is EVM bytecode. To execute these transactions
column6: two new instructions (known as opcodes) have to be added to the EVM: NONCE and PAYGAS. The NONCE opcode tracks the transaction sequence and PAYGAS calculates and withdraws the gas required to execute the transaction from the contract's balance. These new features allow Ethereum to support smart contract wallets natively as the necessary infrastructure is built in to Ethereum's protocol.

column1: Note that EIP-2938 is currently not active. The community is currently favoring EIP-4337 because it does not require changes to the protocol.

column2: but more upgrades are required to make them as decentralized and permissionless as possible. EIP-4337 is a mature proposal that does not require any changes to Ethereum's protocol
column3: so it is possible that this could be implemented quickly. However
column4: upgrades that alter Ethereum's protocol are currently not in active development
column5: so those changes may take much longer to ship. It is also possible that account abstraction is achieved well enough by EIP-4337 that no protocol changes are ever required.

column1: To onboard more blockchain users and provide a very seamless user experience to them
column2: account abstraction has a major role to play in the way blockchain products are built and utilized. Blockchain technologies keep improving everyday and we will get to see more innovations around account abstraction not only in the Ethereum ecosystem
column3: but also in other blockchain ecosystems as well.

column1: • What is Account Abstraction and Why is Everyone Talking About It?

column2: I will show you how to create a React application with Vite and configure dev container to run it in GitHub Codespaces.

column1: A codespace is a development environment that's hosted in the cloud. You can customise your project for GitHub Codespaces by committing configuration files to your repository
column2: which creates a repeatable codespace configuration for all users of your project.

column1: Currently GitHub Codespaces are available for everyone and you get up to 60 hours per month for free
column2: which should be enough for experiments and pet projects.

column1: Building a React application with Vite.js

column2: I'll be using React with Typescript
column3: but the same would work for React with a raw javascript template.

column1: 1. Build the application - run one of these commands
npm create vite@latest devc-react-app --template react-ts

column2: extra double-dash is needed:

column1: npm create vite@latest devc-react-app -- --template react-ts
yarn create vite devc-react-app --template react-ts
Your application should run on a random port.
Open vite.config.ts and change default export to this:
export default defineConfig({
You need to open the project directory in VS Code and install the Dev Containers extensions.

column2: run the Create Dev Container... command and select the universal template

column1: VS Code will add the dev container configuration file to your project: .devcontainer/devcontainer.json.

column2: you may be prompted by VS Code to open the folder in a dev container.

column1: Let's skip this for now and focus on configuring the dev container first.
Detailed instructions can be found here: Get started with development Containers in Visual Studio Code and here:
Developing inside a Container using Visual Studio Code Remote Development

column2: open .devcontainer/devcontainer.json and configure a few things:
but allows you to assign a name to the port

column1: updateContentCommand - install dependencies when container is created
postAttachCommand - run application when container is ready

You can also configure a file to open automatically in codespaces customizations.codespaces.openFiles or VS Code extensions to be installed in codespaces and dev container customizations.vscode.extensions.

column2: but I will not focus on them here.

column1: ""forwardPorts"": [3000]
""label"": ""React App""
""postAttachCommand"": ""npm run dev""
// Configure tool-specific properties.
""openFiles"": [""src/App.tsx""]

column2: Vite doesn't work in codespaces - even though the application is running
column3: you can't see any page content in a browser.

column2: you need to modify package.json and change the scripts.dev by adding the --host parameter:

column1: ""scripts"": {
This is the trick I couldn't find anywhere and spent a lot of time looking for.
Remainder: this is the command that the dev container runs as ""postAttachCommand"": ""npm run dev"" on startup.
Now you can push the repository to GitHub and open it in Codespaces:
You will see the green text 'codespaces' in the bottom left corner of your browser.
To open a project in a local dev container
column2: you need to:

column1: <li>Open the project folder in VS Code
column2: then you will be asked if you want to open it in the dev container. You can open it or clone to the dev container

column1: Reopen in dev container - files stay where they are and you work on them directly from the linked Docker volume
Clone in volume - preferred for Windows users with WSL2. It clones a copy of the project into a Docker container and volume. This option is much faster on Windows.
Detailed instructions can be found here: Get started with development Containers in Visual Studio Code and here:
Developing inside a Container using Visual Studio Code Remote Development
If you don't have your repository locally and want to clone it directly from GitHub into a local dev container
column2: you can do this from within VS Code:

column1: > Dev containers: Clone repository in Container Volume
To run a React application created with CRA (create-react-app) you need to change start command in package.json:
""scripts"": {
""start"": ""BROWSER=none WDS_SOCKET_PORT=0 react-scripts start""
This is needed to fix the hot reload after each change.
